title: components
description: The components/ directory is where you put all your Vue components.

children.value: directory is where you put all your Vue components which can then be imported inside your pages or other components (
Nuxt automatically imports any components in your
directory (along with components that are registered by any modules you may be using).

props.code:
| components/
--| TheHeader.vue
--| TheFooter.vue

children.value: directory is scanned. If you want to add other directories, or change how the components are scanned within a subfolder of this directory, you can add additional directories to the configuration:
Any nested directories need to be added first as they are scanned in order.
By default, any file with an extension specified in the

is treated as a component.
If you need to restrict the file extensions that should be registered as components, you can use the extended form of the components directory declaration and its
If you have a component in nested directories such as:

props.code:
| components/
--| base/
----| foo/
------| Button.vue

children.value: ... then the component's name will be based on its own path directory and filename, with duplicate segments being removed. Therefore, the component's name will be:

props.code: <BaseFooButton />

children.value: For clarity, we recommend that the component's filename matches its name. (So, in the example above, you could rename
If you want to auto-import components based only on its name, not path, then you need to set
using extended form of the configuration object:
This registers the components using the same strategy as used in Nuxt 2. For example,
If you want to use the Vue
syntax, then you will need to use the

props.code:
<template>
  <component :is="clickable ? MyButton : 'div'" />
</template>

<script setup>
const MyButton = resolveComponent('MyButton')
</script>

children.value: to handle dynamic components, make sure not to insert anything but the name of the component, which must be a string and not a variable.
Alternatively, though not recommended, you can register all your components globally, which will create async chunks for all your components and make them available throughout your application.
You can also selectively register some components globally by placing them in a
option can also be set per component directory.
To dynamically import a component (also known as lazy-loading a component) all you need to do is add the
This is particularly useful if the component is not always needed. By using the
prefix you can delay loading the component code until the right moment, which can be helpful for optimizing your JavaScript bundle size.
You can also explicitly import components from
if you want or need to bypass Nuxt's auto-importing functionality.
component for purposely rendering a component only on client side. To import a component only on the client, register the component in a client-side only plugin.
<!-- this component will only be rendered on client-side -->

If a component is meant to be rendered only client-side, you can add the

props.code:
| components/
--| Comments.client.vue

children.value: <!-- this component will only be rendered on client side -->
This feature only works with Nuxt auto-imports and
imports. Explicitly importing these components from their real paths does not convert them into client-only components.
components are rendered only after being mounted. To access the rendered template using
components can either be used on their own or paired with a
Standalone server components will always be rendered on the server. When their props update, this will result in a network request that will update the rendered HTML in-place.
Server components are currently experimental and in order to use them, you need to enable the 'component islands' feature in your nuxt.config:
Now you can register server-only components with the
suffix and use them anywhere in your application automatically.

props.code:
| components/
--| HighlightedMarkdown.server.vue

children.value: this will automatically be rendered on the server, meaning your markdown parsing + highlighting
libraries are not included in your client bundle.
Slots are not supported by server components in their current state of development.
Please note that there is a known issue with using async code in a server component. It will lead to a hydration mismatch error on initial render. See
. Until there is a workaround, server-components must be synchronous.
components are two 'halves' of a component and can be used in advanced use cases for separate implementations of a component on server and client side.

props.code:
| components/
--| Comments.client.vue
--| Comments.server.vue

children.value: <!-- this component will render Comments.server server-side then Comments.client once mounted in client-side -->
It is essential that the client half of the component can 'hydrate' the server-rendered HTML. That is, it should render the same HTML on initial load, or you will experience a hydration mismatch.
component to render a component only during development.
The content will not be included in production builds and tree-shaken.
<!-- this component will only be rendered during development -->
Making Vue component libraries with automatic tree-shaking and component registration is super easy ✨
hook to extend the directory list without requiring user configuration in your Nuxt module.
Imagine a directory structure like this:

props.code:
| node_modules/
---| awesome-ui/
------| components/
---------| Alert.vue
---------| Button.vue
------| nuxt.js
| pages/
---| index.vue
| nuxt.config.js
